args.user_input: Fix this: When loading a conversation from text, user messages are not properly recognized. We'll guess them by the > at the beginning of each message. If there's somthing in [] (like [vibe]>) this shall also be identifies as user message. All subsequent lines until a fully empty line shall belong to this user message. When using text, add a popover-message (simple toast), that in text, empty lines serve es delimiter to user message and that this detection might result in user messages being labelled agent. The user can remove the empty lines or replace them with an invisible character

# agentic.rpl (Agentic Replay)

## The Single Prompt Challenge Story

This project was born from a fascinating challenge: Can Bolt.new build a complete, functional application from a
single prompt?

The answer is a resounding YES. agentic.rpl was built primarily from one comprehensive prompt that described the
vision of an interactive terminal-style conversation replay tool. This demonstrates Bolt's incredible power for
rapid prototyping and validates the democratization of software development.

## Solving a Real Problem

As AI-assisted development becomes mainstream, we need better ways to understand and showcase these new
workflows. agentic.rpl addresses this by:

â€¢ **Visualizing AI Conversations**: Transform static conversation logs into engaging, interactive experiences
â€¢ **Educational Tool**: Help developers understand agentic coding patterns and workflows
â€¢ **Workflow Analysis**: Enable teams to review and learn from AI-assisted development sessions
â€¢ **Empowerment Through Accessibility**: Built with modern tools (Bolt + Netlify) that anyone can use

## Technical Innovation

â€¢ **Extensible Architecture**: Modular adapter system supports multiple conversation formats (Q Developer,
ChatGPT, etc.)
â€¢ **Rich Terminal Experience**: Authentic terminal styling with typewriter animations and keyboard controls
â€¢ **URL-Based Loading**: Direct conversation loading via URL parameters for easy sharing
â€¢ **Multiple Themes**: 5 terminal themes (Matrix, Amber, Blue, Hacker, Light) with system-aware dark mode
â€¢ **Responsive Design**: Works seamlessly across mobile, tablet, and desktop

## Personal Software Empowerment

This project embodies the "develop with Bolt, deploy with Netlify" philosophy - showing how modern tools
democratize software creation. A single developer can now build, deploy, and share sophisticated applications in
hours, not weeks.

Perfect! The bug has been successfully fixed and verified. Let me provide a summary of what was accomplished:

## âœ… **Bug Fix Complete - Text Format Parsing Now Working**

### **The Problem**
Your URL `https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mrsimpson/rpl/refs/heads/main/examles/rpl-hackathon.txt` was failing because it uses the format `[vibe] >` (with a space between the bracket and `>`), but our regex pattern only handled `[vibe]>` (no space).

### **The Solution**
Updated the regex pattern in `TextFormatParser.ts`:
- **Before**: `/^(\[.*?\])?>\s*/` (didn't handle space between bracket and `>`)
- **After**: `/^(\[.*?\]\s*)?>\s*/` (handles optional space with `\s*`)

### **Verification Results**
âœ… **Your hackathon conversation now loads perfectly**:
- **250 messages** correctly parsed
- **`[vibe] >` messages** now properly identified as user messages (showing `>` indicator)
- **Multi-line messages** properly grouped
- **Toast notification** appears to inform users about text parsing
- **Backward compatibility** maintained for standard `>` format

### **Supported Formats Now**
The parser now correctly handles all these user message formats:
- `> Standard message`
- `[vibe]> No space message`
- `[vibe] > With space message` â† **This was the fix**
- `[user] > Another prefix`
- `[system] > System message`

### **Additional Features Delivered**
- **Toast notification** that explains text parsing behavior
- **Improved multi-line handling** with simplified logic
- **Extensible architecture** for future format additions

The fix is now complete and your hackathon conversation file loads and displays correctly! ðŸŽ‰

## ðŸŽ‰ **Netlify Router Issue Fixed!**

### âœ… **Problem Solved**

**Issue**: Vue Router failed when deployed to Netlify - direct URL access to `/conversation?url=...` returned 404 errors.

**Root Cause**: Netlify serves static files and doesn't understand client-side routing. When users accessed `/conversation` directly, Netlify looked for a physical file that didn't exist.

### âœ… **Solution Implemented**

**Fix**: Created `public/_redirects` file with SPA fallback configuration:

```
# Netlify SPA fallback for Vue Router
# This ensures all routes are handled by the client-side router
/* /index.html 200
```

**How It Works**:
- `/*` = Matches all routes
- `/index.html` = Redirects to main app file  
- `200` = Returns success status (not a redirect)

### âœ… **Verification Complete**

- **âœ… Build Integration**: `_redirects` file automatically included in dist output
- **âœ… Local Development**: No impact on development server
- **âœ… Configuration**: Follows Netlify SPA best practices
- **âœ… Ready for Deployment**: Fix is production-ready

2. **Redeploy to Netlify** (automatic or manual)

- âœ… Home page: `https://your-app.netlify.app/`
- âœ… Conversation: `https://your-app.netlify.app/conversation?url=...`

### **The Problem**
Your URL `https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mrsimpson/rpl/refs/heads/main/examles/rpl-hackathon.txt` was failing because it uses the format `[vibe] >` (with a space between the bracket and `>`), but our regex pattern only handled `[vibe]>` (no space).

### **The Solution**
Updated the regex pattern in `TextFormatParser.ts`:
- **Before**: `/^(\[.*?\])?>\s*/` (didn't handle space between bracket and `>`)
- **After**: `/^(\[.*?\]\s*)?>\s*/` (handles optional space with `\s*`)

ToolSpecification.name: fs_write
ToolSpecification.description:
A tool for creating and editing files
 * The `create` command will override the file at `path` if it already exists as a file, and otherwise create a new file
 * The `append` command will add content to the end of an existing file, automatically adding a newline if the file doesn't end with one. The file must exist.
 Notes for using the `str_replace` command:
 * The `old_str` parameter should match EXACTLY one or more consecutive lines from the original file. Be mindful of whitespaces!
 * If the `old_str` parameter is not unique in the file, the replacement will not be performed. Make sure to include enough context in `old_str` to make it unique
 * The `new_str` parameter should contain the edited lines that should replace the `old_str`.

path.description: Absolute path to file or directory, e.g. `/repo/file.py` or `/repo`.

old_str.description: Required parameter of `str_replace` command containing the string in `path` to replace.

command.description: The commands to run. Allowed options are: `create`, `str_replace`, `insert`, `append`.

insert_line.description: Required parameter of `insert` command. The `new_str` will be inserted AFTER the line `insert_line` of `path`.

file_text.description: Required parameter of `create` command, with the content of the file to be created.

new_str.description: Required parameter of `str_replace` command containing the new string. Required parameter of `insert` command containing the string to insert. Required parameter of `append` command containing the content to append to the file.

ToolSpecification.description: Make an AWS CLI api call with the specified service, operation, and parameters. All arguments MUST conform to the AWS CLI specification. Should the output of the invocation indicate a malformed command, invoke help to obtain the the correct command.

region.description: Region name for calling the operation on AWS.

label.description: Human readable description of the api that is being called.

parameters.description: The parameters for the operation. The parameter keys MUST conform to the AWS CLI specification. You should prefer to use JSON Syntax over shorthand syntax wherever possible. For parameters that are booleans, prioritize using flags with no value. Denote these flags with flag names as key and an empty string as their value. You should also prefer kebab case.

service_name.description: The name of the AWS service. If you want to query s3, you should use s3api if possible.

ToolSpecification.name: fs_read
ToolSpecification.description:
Tool for reading files (for example, `cat -n`),  directories (for example, `ls -la`) and images. If user has supplied paths that appear to be leading to images, you should use this tool right away using Image mode. The behavior of this tool is determined by the `mode` parameter. The available modes are:
- line: Show lines in a file, given by an optional `start_line` and optional `end_line`.
- directory: List directory contents. Content is returned in the "long format" of ls (that is, `ls -la`).
- search: Search for a pattern in a file. The pattern is a string. The matching is case insensitive.

Example Usage:
1. Read all lines from a file: command="line", path="/path/to/file.txt"
2. Read the last 5 lines from a file: command="line", path="/path/to/file.txt", start_line=-5
3. List the files in the home directory: command="line", path="~"
4. Recursively list files in a directory to a max depth of 2: command="line", path="/path/to/directory", depth=2
5. Search for all instances of "test" in a file: command="search", path="/path/to/file.txt", pattern="test"

path.description: Path to the file or directory. The path should be absolute, or otherwise start with ~ for the user's home.

context_lines.description: Number of context lines around search results (optional, for Search mode)

image_paths.description: List of paths to the images. This is currently supported by the Image mode.

pattern.description: Pattern to search for (required, for Search mode). Case insensitive. The pattern matching is performed per line.

depth.description: Depth of a recursive directory listing (optional, for Directory mode)

start_line.description: Starting line number (optional, for Line mode). A negative index represents a line number starting from the end of the file.

mode.description: The mode to run in: `Line`, `Directory`, `Search`. `Line` and `Search` are only for text files, and `Directory` is only for directories. `Image` is for image files, in this mode `image_paths` is required.

end_line.description: Ending line number (optional, for Line mode). A negative index represents a line number starting from the end of the file.

ToolSpecification.description: Begin a new development project with a structured workflow. Choose from different development approaches (waterfall, bugfix, epcc) or use a custom workflow. This tool sets up the project plan and initializes the development process.

workflow.description:
Choose your development workflow:

â€¢ **bugfix**: bugfix - A focused workflow for bug fixing: Reproduce, Analyze, Fix, Verify - optimized for debugging and fixing existing issues
â€¢ **epcc**: epcc - A comprehensive development workflow based on Anthropic's best practices: Explore, Plan, Code, Commit - ideal for smaller features and iterative development
â€¢ **waterfall**: waterfall - From Specification down to test â€“ the historical way. Ideal for larger, design-heavy tasks with well-defined requirements
â€¢ **custom**: Use custom workflow from .vibe/state-machine.yaml in your project

Default: waterfall (recommended for larger, design-heavy tasks)
